Clark J. Charnetski Papers, 1955-1971
titlepage.author:
Finding aid created by
Patricia Ryan, May 2014

did.abstract: Papers of Clark J. Charnetski (1942- ), a physicist who specialized in holographic research and development at Conductron Corporation in Ann Arbor, Mich., where he was the Associate Research Physicist and Chief Holographer. This collection contains materials relating to the administrative background of Conductron Corporation, materials relating to holography in Michigan collected by Charnetski, papers and presentations given by Charnetski and Conductron Corporation, notes, drawings, information relating to patents of Charnetski and others at Conductron, as well as detailed papers regarding the projects that Charnetski conducted while at Conductron.

repository.corpname: Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

acqinfo.p: Collection was donated by Clark J. Charnetski (donor no. 11060) in February 2014.

accruals.p: Periodic additions to the records expected.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open to research.

userestrict.p: Copyright is held by the Regents of the University of Michigan.

prefercite.p: [item], folder, box, Clark J. Charnetski papers, Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

bioghist.p: Clark J. Charnetski was born in 1942 in Menominee, Mich. to Victor and Theresa Charnetski. He received his Bachelor of Science degree in Physics from the University of Michigan in 1964. One year later, he married Mary Ann Lund. After his graduation from the University of Michigan, Charnetski taught high school physics and physical science in Walled Lake, Mich. for two years.

In 1966, Charnetski joined the Optics Research department of Conductron Corporation in Ann Arbor, Mich. Conductron Corporation was a 1960's electronics and radar research firm which was founded by Keeve (Kip) Siegel, a former Physics professor at the University of Michigan, with the goal of commercializing and furthering the work of the University of Michigan's Radiation Laboratory during the developmental years of holography. Conductron was key to early holographic research and innovation and many of the methods and techniques used today, including full-color holography, can trace their roots back to Conductron.

During his time at Conductron, Charnetski conducted extensive research in holography. Charnetski was the Associate Research Physicist and Chief Holographer in the Electro-Optical Department at Conductron and worked mainly in commercial holographic displays. He produced the master hologram and devised the means to print 500,000 holograms for binding into World Book's 1967 Science Year annual supplement, which at the time was the largest order for holograms ever made. In 1968, Charnetski made the four 18 by 24 inch holograms used for the General Motors (GM) Fisher Body display in GM's new office building in New York City, which were the largest size holograms of their time.

scopecontent.p: The Clark J. Charnetski papers contain materials relating to the administrative background of Conductron Corporation, materials relating to holography in Michigan collected by Charnetski, papers and presentations given by Charnetski and Conductron Corporation, notes, drawings, information relating to patents of Charnetski and others at Conductron, as well as detailed papers regarding the projects that Charnetski conducted while at Conductron. This collection is of value to those interested in the history of holography, especially as it relates to the state of Michigan. The collection is divided into four series: the Administrative series, the Scientific Works series (divided into three subseries: Collected Materials, Papers and Presentations, and Patents and Inventions), the Projects series, and the Mechanical Drawings series.

The Administrative series (0.8 linear feet, 1965-1971) contains materials relating to Conductron Corporation. This includes business correspondence, articles written about Conductron Corporation, Charnetski's desk calendar with daily notes, annual and monthly reports, company newsletters, holography marketing materials, film samples, staff information, and products and equipment used by Conductron Corporation (including photographs). Notable in this series is information regarding the holograms used in World Book's 1967 Science Year.

did.unittitle: Kingsport Press and Field Enterprises World Book Science Year supplement
Procedure governing relocation of Ann Arbor Conductron personnel to St. Charles, Missouri
Three B Optical Company production bulletin
University of Michigan photographs of equipment

scopecontent.p: The Scientific works series (0.8 linear feet, 1955-1970) is a collection of materials related to the scientific study of holography. The series has been divided into three subseries: Collected materials, Papers and presentations, and Patents and inventions.

The Collected materials subseries (0.2 linear feet, 1955-1970) contains materials relating to Emmett Leith, Juris Upatnieks, and George Stroke and their work with holography at the University of Michigan. In addition, materials relating to other companies and physicists throughout Michigan and their holographic innovations are included in this series.

The Papers and presentations subseries (0.4 linear feet, 1966-1970) contains all of the publications written by Charnetski in addition to marked up drafts and notes. Presentations given by Charnetski to different groups (with some photographs of presentations) and papers and presentations given by others at Conductron are also included in this series.

did.unittitle: American Institute of Chemical Engineers presentation
The Impact of Holography on the Consumer
Optical Society of America Annual meetings
Optical Society of America Fall meeting
Optical Society of America Spring meetings
Photographs of Optical Society of America presentation

scopecontent.p: Patents and inventions subseries (0.2 linear feet, 1966-1970) relates to materials regarding patents and inventions of Clark Charnetski, as well as those of others at Conductron Corporation. Included in this series are invention disclosures, contracts, and notes regarding inventions, as well as a list of Conductron personnel invention disclosures.

did.unittitle: Patent information on focused image reflection holograms

scopecontent.p: The Projects series (1 linear foot, 1967-1970) holds materials relating to the various holographic projects that Charnetski worked on during his time at Conductron Corporation. This includes notes taken by Charnetski regarding projects, project sketches drawn by Charnetski, photographs corresponding to projects, and project orders and other processing documents.

did.unittitle: Mass production of reflection film holograms
National Cash Register Company hologram inquiry
Project 1017 General Motors Fisher Body display
Project 1090 Hoffmann-La Roche spastic colon holograms
Project 1160 General Motors flying saucer holograms
Project 1198 Hoffman-La Roche eye reach III holograms
Project 3412 Marketing masters for reflection hologram samples
Project 7182 Focused image reflection hologram of F-111
Project 7187 Clock, magnifier, and molecule holograms
Project 7190 Focused image reflection holograms of F-4 airplane
Reflection film holograms for point-of-purchase store displays
Three Dimensional Image Systems and Optical data Processing Systems Research and development

scopecontent.p: The Mechanical drawings series (0.5 linear feet, 1966-1969) is a collection of various mechanical drawings relating to holography.

did.unittitle: Holographic plate holder assembly 8 by 10 inch

relatedmaterial.head: Related Collections
relatedmaterial.p:
The Bentley Historical Library holds the following related manuscript collections:
Emmett N. Leith papers, 1936 and 1954-2005. Finding aid available online
Keeve Milton Siegel papers, 1953-1983. Finding aid available online
Juris Upatnieks papers, 1963-1994. Finding aid available online
